docs.lead_paragraph: Is being a doctor becoming too hard? I used to think so when I was an intern, when being a doctor was too hard. Back then I remember wandering the hospital wards, wondering how I was going to get through another night on call, until I realized that my patients were helping me. Nowadays, I think the practice of medicine is hard for different reasons. Not long ago I saw a new patient in my cardiology clinic. He was an elderly man who spoke only French, so I had to call for an interpreter. When I finally got someone on the phone, my patient told me that he had been having palpitations. Since his EKG was abnormal, I decided to order some tests.

headline.main: That Ounce Of Prevention Grew Too Big

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar's Cases article describes changes she holds effect soon-to-be doctors in medical schools; describes decline in number of primary care physicians and suggests reasons for decrease (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New research and studies that are under way are leading many heart disease experts to say they expect that the current guidelines for lowering cholesterol may not be stringent enough. Lower may be better, perhaps even stopping heart disease in its tracks, they say. A new study looking at the growth of plaque in arteries of heart disease patients came to that conclusion. And while medical experts are awaiting the results of studies asking if lower levels also lead to fewer heart attacks and deaths, many say they are betting that the answer will be yes.

headline.main: Just How Low Can You Go? A Cholesterol Challenge

docs.abstract: Recent data from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on heart disease and efforts to reduce cholesterol show 60 percent of people diagnosed with high cholesterol did not know of condition; holds that of those people aware of problem only 14 percent take cholesterol-reducing drug and seven percent are able to get levels within suggested limits; Dr James I Cleeman, national cholesterol education program coordinator for heart institute, contends that doctors are underprescribing needed drugs; disagreement about when doctors should intervene when patient wants to reduce cholesterol with diet and exercise is discussed; effectiveness of statins, which reduce cholesterol levels, discussed; photos; graph (L)
docs.snippet: New research and studies that are under way are leading many heart disease experts to say they expect that the current guidelines for lowering cholesterol may not be stringent enough.    Lower may be better, perhaps even stopping heart disease in its...

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study finds that virtual colonoscopy, a method that uses a C.T. scanner for colon cancer screening, can be just as effective as traditional colonoscopy in finding polyps, the mushroomlike growths from which most cancers arise. Patients having the 15-minute virtual screening test simply lie down and hold their breath for about 10 seconds, exhale, then hold their breath again while a C.T. scanner X-rays their colons, creating detailed, three-dimensional images of the walls. With traditional colonoscopy, patients are sedated while a doctor threads a long flexible tube into the colon, spending half an hour viewing its walls in much the same sort of detail. Then they wait in a recovery room for about an hour as the sedative wears off.

headline.main: A Gentler Type of Colonoscopy Is Found Effective

docs.abstract: Virtual colonscopy, which uses CT scanner to diagnose polyps in colon, is topic of recent study directed by Dr Perry J Pickhardt, University of Wisconsin radiology professor; 1,233 people ages 50 to 79 participated in study published in New England Journal of Medicine that shows no distinct difference in accuracy between virtual and traditional colonoscopies; virtual procedure does not require sedation or long tubes and 70 percent of study participants rated it more convenient than optical procedure; colonoscopy, sigmoidoscopy, barium enemas, and fecal occult blood tests discussed and compared; drawing; photos (L)
docs.snippet: A new study finds that virtual colonoscopy, a method that uses a C.T. scanner for colon cancer screening, can be just as effective as traditional colonoscopy in finding polyps, the mushroomlike growths from which most cancers arise.    Patients...

docs.lead_paragraph: She already knows how to read an EKG. And she was taught to measure blood pressure three years ago. But in her fourth year of medical school, Hilda Fernandez is learning how to quantify hope. One of a growing number of medical students taking courses in social activism, Ms. Fernandez is trying to move beyond the straightforward science that has occupied so much of her time during her professional education.

headline.main: Medical Students Go Beyond Books to Learn About Activism

docs.abstract: Growing number of medical schools are offering courses in social activism; student projects are discussed; historic examples of doctors who made difference in policy detailed; medical student Hilda Fernandez gives view of course taught at Montefiore Medical Center in Bronx (NYC); photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many American women either know little about a common virus that causes most cases of cervical cancer or have serious misunderstandings about it, a study reported yesterday. Writing in the journal Cancer, researchers said that in order to combat the papillomavirus, health officials needed to do a better job educating the public as testing for it becomes a routine part of women's health care.
docs.abstract: Dr Sue J Goldie, Harvard School of Public Health researcher, publishes study findings in journal Cancer that show American women lack understanding about papilloma virus (HPV) which is most widespread sexually transmitted disease and leading cause of cervical cancer; only 27 percent of women surveyed had heard of HPV; need for better testing and education about disease discussed (S)
docs.snippet: Many American women either know little about a common virus that causes most cases of cervical cancer or have serious misunderstandings about it, a study reported yesterday.    Writing in the journal Cancer, researchers said that in order to combat...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''A Map of the Child: A Pediatrician's Tour of the Body,'' by Dr. Darshak Sanghavi. Henry Holt & Company, $24. Unless they are textbooks, books do not generally have chapters named after human organ systems. This one does, but it is more than just anatomy. Rather, it is a medical tour, sometimes lyrical, of children's insides, an excursion modeled after the residency rounds the author experienced at Boston's Children's Hospital.
docs.abstract: Dr Darshak Sanghavi's book Map of the Child gives body part by body part medical tour of child's developing anatomy; various illnesses discussed; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study finds little evidence, despite some earlier reports, that breast-feeding reduces a child's risk of high blood pressure in adulthood. ''Our analysis suggests that any effect of breast-feeding on blood pressure is modest and of limited clinical or public health importance,'' the study's authors wrote in a report in BMJ, the British medical journal.
docs.abstract: Dr Christopher G Owen of St George's Hospital Medical School (London) leads study that examines 29 previous studies on breast feeding and possible link between nursing and reduced risk of high blood pressure in adulthood; study, published in journal BMJ, finds no concrete evidence of blood pressure related benefits from breast feeding; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study finds little evidence, despite some earlier reports, that breast-feeding reduces a child's risk of high blood pressure in adulthood.    ''Our analysis suggests that any effect of breast-feeding on blood pressure is modest and of limited...

docs.lead_paragraph: As parents and doctors struggle with an epidemic of childhood obesity in America, Anne Youngquist worries about a subtler menace that may not threaten her three children for decades: heart disease. About eight years ago, after learning that her husband, Rod, suffered from elevated cholesterol, she started having their children's cholesterol checked, too. Bryce, at 16 their oldest child, went on a low dose of cholesterol-lowering statin drugs three years ago. Alyssa, 14, has also gone on statins. Eight-year-old Brady is not on medication, but he, too, joins the family in a diet low in fat; to the Youngquists 2 percent milk tastes like heavy cream.
docs.abstract: Fifteen percent of children in US are considered overweight and four new studies on children and heart disease point out importance of preventative measures at early age if heart disease risk factors are apparent; Dr Henry C McGill Jr, Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research (San Antonio) senior scientist emeritus, holds that life style changes for healthy heart are best made in childhood before unhealthy behavioral patterns are established; Dr Stephen B Hulley, University of California (San Francisco) epidemiology and biostatistics chairman, however, feels too much emphasis on condition that will not likely present itself for 50 years could have negative emotional effects on children; some other experts believe that good overall approach to children's health is best way to impact future health of heart; photos; charts (L)
docs.snippet: As parents and doctors struggle with an epidemic of childhood obesity in America, Anne Youngquist worries about a subtler menace that may not threaten her three children for decades: heart disease.    About eight years ago, after learning that her...

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent years, ''tried and true'' remedies for children have fallen like autumn leaves when medical scientists discovered that the treatment was either worthless or worse than the disease. Hence the passing of Merthiolate and Mercurochrome for cuts and abrasions, aspirin for fever, boric acid for diaper rash and now syrup of ipecac for ingested poisons. Every child care book on my shelf, including the 1993 edition of ''Caring for Your Baby and Young Child'' from the American Academy of Pediatrics, recommends keeping ipecac on hand to induce vomiting when a child swallows drugs or other substances that could be toxic.

headline.main: Antidotes for Poisons Are Just a Phone Call Away

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column updates how to handle situations where poisoning is suspected and outlines preventive measures to reduce likelihood of poisoning in first place; specific changes in use of ipecac discussed; poison control center information given; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: In recent years, ''tried and true'' remedies for children have fallen like autumn leaves when medical scientists discovered that the treatment was either worthless or worse than the disease. Hence the passing of Merthiolate and Mercurochrome for cuts...

docs.lead_paragraph: Neurologists suffer many more migraines than the general population, researchers have found, and for those neurologists who specialize in treating headaches, the incidence is even higher. ''Anecdotally, as a migraineur, I just kind of observed that other neurologists seemed to have migraines, also,'' said the lead author of the study, Dr. Randolph W. Evans of the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.
docs.abstract: Dr Randolph W Evans, Baylor College of Medicine (Houston) researcher, leads survey of neurologists that shows significantly higher percentage of neurologists suffer migraines than general population; study, published in journal Neurology, finds 58 percent of female and 34 percent of male neurologists had at least one migraine in past year compared to 18 percent of women and 6 percent of men in general; drawing (S)
